ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Also had section
Virtual Section
Weekly discussion section.
weekly section
Live virtual lecture and live virtual seminar
Some virtual seminar elements, but mostly live virtual lectures.
Live discussion sections
weekly zoom discussion section
Accompanied by Zoom sections
Live virtual lecture and virtual discussion section.
There were also discussion sections once a week, and student presentations.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I improved my understanding of climate collapses and how climate changes have impacted civilizations of the past. I also improved my ability to read academic material over short amount of time.
I learned how the study of collapse has grown and changed over time. Also gained a great understanding of the potential causes and examples of collapse over the long course of human civilization.
The controversy and quantification of societal collapse (and why it's largely caused by the environment).
Cutting-edge debates in the collapse literature
This class is a very good survey into the archaeological study of societal collapse. I was able to glean a lot about how modern societies may collapse as well.
An understanding of collapse theories and causes. An exploration of the history of societal collapse.
I learned about the importance of climate reconstructions to learning about human history.
I learned about different instances of societal collapse and the paleoclimatic data that suggest them.

I developed a wide array of skills related to analyzing collapsed societies and civilizations. I learned how to cut through inaccurate or unclear evidence and determine which is useful for explaining a given collapse. I also learned a lot about many different civilizations throughout history through the lens of collapse.

I have a general sense of the role of megadroughts in old civilization "collapse." I also understand what collapse is and why it continues to be such a divisive term.
I have a much more specific knowledge of the collapse case that I studied for my presentation and final paper. This includes the political structure of this society, its anthropogenic-environment interactions, and the rough chronology of its collapse.
I learned about various large societal "collapses" as well as various scholarly approaches to societal collapse in general, particularly the role that climate can play in each of the scenarios.
I learned about various theories of collapse, their strengths and weaknesses, and what it means for a society to collapse.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strength: the classes exposes you in a great variety of different theories, and types of  data and dat representations/ interpretations which allows students to make their own conclusions and think about the studied material. Very interesting material and the last studied collapse cases give you an understanding of more modern sociopolitical events. The instructor is also great.

To improve: sometimes the lecture was too long to keep being concentrated all through it. Having some more interactive elements like the multiple choice questions feature integrated in zoom or having a 5 minute break in the middle of the lecture would be helpful to refresh our concentration.

The class was extremely informative. Professor Weiss is a fixture in the field of collapse and Near East research, and his insights are great. I think the course could be improved by the use of clearer presentations. While Professor Weiss has great commentary throughout lectures, the presentations are rarely as informative.
I thought that there were too many student presentations. But Professor Weiss is a great professor who cares about his students

The course material is really interesting and I enjoyed Professor Weiss providing his expertise. Plus, making student presentations was enjoyable. But, I found the course reading to be a little too much. Properly doing all the reading in some weeks was frankly impossible to do while balancing my other classes and commitments. And, many of the papers were difficult to read and highly technical. While the topics they covered were interesting, I found it hard to enjoy doing the reading. The course also felt a little disorganized when it came to things like the presentations - I felt like we were always a little behind there. But overall, I enjoyed the course.
I would have liked to have read the papers before they were presented on, instead of after.

I thought the course's material was well organized and Professor Weiss is clearly an expert on the subject. However, the lack of an enrollment cap combined with individual presentations each week took up the vast majority of class time. Having a smaller class or removing or shortening these presentations would have made each class more interesting and insightful.

95% of the course was just students presenting based on the readings for that week. I would have preferred to have been lectured by the professor, since he did not lecture at all, with the exception of the first two weeks.

Strengths: I appreciated that we read a few differing pieces on the definition of 'collapse' to preface actual societal collapse cases. 'Collapse' was an unfamiliar term to me before taking this course and it was interesting how quickly my understanding shifted with each work we dissected. Professor Weiss and our TA were also very forgiving and considerate of the circumstances for this year.

Weaknesses: The biggest weakness of this class is the method of delivering presentations. Once we had past the introduction to proxy data and collapse definitions, every class was set up so that we sat through 3-5 presenters for a single collapse case. We often ran out of time, so the number of presenters per class only increased with the semester. My issue with this system is that this course meets only once a week, meaning that students were meant to listen to similar accounts of collapse within a near 2 hour period. We all read the same papers for the presentation day, but only really talked about them in section a week later.
If you didn't complete the readings on time, then it was trickier to follow the presentations. I therefore wonder if short reading responses graded for participation only would help with this problem.

The course, beginning with an overview of various theories of collapse throughout the years and then continuing with a brief survey of major collapses, is a great introduction to this field. Many of the readings were quite interesting, but do suggest a one-sided perspective. I would have liked to see more diversity in the assigned readings, with more articles writing against the purported major role that climate change played in societal collapses. Further, the course was not very well organized. Professor Weiss suddenly changed the class format from seminar to lecture/discussion section, which resulted in the lectures in the second half of the course being exclusively student presentations with very little input from the instructor.
A wide variety of theories are covered, and students are encouraged to look critically at all of them to draw their own conclusions.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The professor was very open to questions and devoted a lot of time to answering them.
I don't think sections were very effective in this class. Bukhu did a fantastic job given the situation, but the course's non-lecture portions could be improved.
I liked how the class was still very synchronous. I felt engaged with the material and the time commitments kept me accountable.

There weren't many pandemic-specific accommodations made outside of the virtual lecture format and virtual discussion sections. I would have liked a lecture recording if possible, as I often found myself wanting to review a specific point in a student presentation but wasn't able to go back and rewatch it.
None felt particularly geared toward it, it worked reasonably

There were no practices put in aside from using Zoom. A couple of the earlier lectures were recorded, before it was decided that recorded lectures would only dissuade students from showing up to live class.
Section made use of breakout rooms in Zoom for mini discussions.

I would suggest for future classes, that face cameras be turned on. I know this probably sounds annoying for students who have yet to take this class, but without this forced "engagement," you'll inevitably distance yourself from the class and its material. Even if face cameras are not mandatory, I would have liked to have done some form of student introduction after schedules were finalized. This class was technically a seminar before it morphed into a lecture, and I believe introductions would foster some semblance of a class vibe.
We never used the raise hand function and barely used chat in Zoom. It wasn't guaranteed that Professor would see a raised hand in a video either, so we had to unmute and jump into the conversation for questions. This makes participation a bit tricky for those who are either more quiet, or who don't have cameras on and are thus harder for Professor to identify.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, it is a great way to fulfill your social science credit and also get an opportunity to improve your academic writing as part of the term and the final papers.
Absolutely. This was a great class, if you are at all interested in ancient societies, collapse research, or archaeology, this could be the class for you.
Interesting material and a very passionate professor.

Yes, I would. Professor Weiss is clearly very passionate about the subject, and if you are at all interested in the history of ancient societies, many of the readings are really interesting (barring the drier archaeological studies).
Yes. This was a great class and I learned a lot, but most importantly I was engaged the entire time and I found everything we looked at to be very fascinating.

Yes. The material is really interesting and Professor Weiss is a fun lecturer. He's clearly an expert in the field and hearing his perspective on topics is pretty cool. The required workload is also pretty low. There is an insane amount of reading, but luckily you don't really need to do it very thoroughly unless you are making a presentation. The course could be better organized. But overall, the material is interesting and it's a pretty low-stress class.
Yes! It was so interesting to see the different directions everyone took their presentations. It really felt like the class had something for everyone.

I would definitely recommend it to anybody looking to learn more about past civilizations' collapses. You don't need much background knowledge to get a lot out of the course, and you'll come away with a strong understanding of collapse literature and the importance of paleoclimate research and proxy data.
Yes! It was a very interesting class for me since it is the first class where I learned about paleoclimate data.

Yes!! Professor Harvey Weiss is a real character with some very strongly held beliefs on the topic, but also a deep knowledge of the scholarship on the issue and that makes for a super engaging class. Most of the class was taken up by student presentations after week five, but they covered such a wide array of topics and Prof. Weisss interjections and questions kept it spicy. Do not go into the course of youre expecting a serious course that will unpack the implications of climate change, but if youre willing to go along for the (often quite fun) ride and learn some very fascinating archaeological perspectives on societal collapse the class is amazing.
I would, but I would make them aware that much of the course is just students presenting, which may be disappointing to some who wished to hear the professor lecture.

Perhaps in a live setting, I would. I was among the students without their cameras turned on, and it sometimes felt a bit sad that the class had to be held in this format. Professor Weiss is personable and understanding, but as with the class style, his own personal style felt stifled by a sudden need to teach classes online.
This is a manageable class for people of all majors. You won't have any grade certainty for the entirety of the semester, and that may influence your decision to take the class. It is low workload for those who have stressful schedules, but I barely had any sense of how I was doing, which was its own source of stress at times.

Yes. This class is great for students with an interest in environmental studies and past societies. It provides a different viewpoint to the mainstream perspective and I encourage students to exercise their critical thinking and analytical skills when thinking about the various theories.

I would recommend this class to students interested in how societies function and especially the interplay between society and the environment. Some background in environmental science, or at least understanding graphs from that field, is helpful, but not required if you are interested.
